header.title: The Scroll of Set - Issue Number 157, Volume XXIV-3, June 1998
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Setianism, Chaos Magic, Nagualism, Candomblé, Philosophy

central_thesis: This issue of 'The Scroll of Set' serves as a comprehensive collection of Setian philosophical explorations, magical methodologies, and community insights. It collectively advances the understanding and practical application of core Setian principles like Xeper and Remanifestation within diverse occult contexts, emphasizing individual self-transformation, the operative side of magic, and a unique Setian perspective on various esoteric traditions and life experiences.

structure_content.chapter_title: A Few Words about the Recent Houston Regional Conclave - by Don Webb V°, High Priest of Set
structure_content.summary: This section details the significant 'Æon-changing events' at a Setian conclave, including leadership changes within the Orders of the Trapezoid, Leviathan, and Uart, recognition of members, and the execution of intense ritual workings such as shape-shifting, Saturnine magic, Lady Arkte, and the forging of a Temple egregore, all fostering 'Innu' (esoteric insight and exchange).

structure_content.chapter_title: A Word on Words - by James Foster I°
structure_content.summary: This article defines 'Æonic Words' (e.g., Xeper, Thelema, Agape) as 'worlds' that create environments for adherents, clarifying that experiencing Xeper does not require prior engagement with older Æonic Words. It differentiates these from 'Æon-enhancing Words' (e.g., Runa, Remanifest) which shape existing Æons, and emphasizes that initiates may move between different 'worlds' rather than being confined to a single one.

structure_content.chapter_title: Some Guidelines for Setian Email Communication and List Participation - by Walter Radtke III°
structure_content.summary: This practical guide offers essential advice for Setians to engage in respectful, clear, and empathetic email communication. It stresses the importance of avoiding patronizing, sarcastic, or accusatory tones, understanding diverse backgrounds, maintaining humility, and recognizing the limitations of email in conveying full meaning, advocating for off-line resolution of conflicts.

structure_content.chapter_title: Arkte's Lair - by Lilith Aquino IV°
structure_content.summary: This brief announcement informs members about 'Arkte's Lair,' the official newsletter of Arkte (an element of the Order of the Vampyre), which will be available by subscription to all Temple of Set members and automatically to Arkte members.

structure_content.chapter_title: How to Create a Ka - by Don Webb V°
structure_content.summary: This section elucidates the concept of 'ka' as a changeless force that manifests in the world, embodying purpose and guiding actions. Using an engineering project as an example, it illustrates how a shared intention brings a 'ka' into being, informing success and failure, and explains how larger 'kaw' (plural of ka) like a corporate profile can subsume smaller ones, highlighting the individual's power to create and utilize kaw.

structure_content.chapter_title: Gates of Hell Pylon - by James Foster I°
structure_content.summary: This notice announces the online presence of the official Gates of Hell Pylon Web-Site, updating on its features and acknowledging contributors. It signifies the Pylon's digital presence and its role within the 'World of Horrors' for the Setian community.

structure_content.chapter_title: Announcing 'Black Iron One' - by David R. Ondrejko II°
structure_content.summary: This section announces a Setian gathering, 'Black Iron One,' hosted by the Nephren-Ka Pylon in Pittsburgh, PA, to commemorate H.P. Lovecraft's birthday. The event will include lectures, workshops, readings of Lovecraft's works, and social companionship for Setians.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Order of Leviathan Online - by Larry Evans III°
structure_content.summary: This short announcement informs readers that The Order of Leviathan has established a new and long-term online presence in cyberspace, inviting members to visit.

structure_content.chapter_title: Remanifesting the Trapezoid Principle as a Tool for Change - by Jeff Owrey I°
structure_content.summary: This in-depth essay explores the application of nagualism's 'assemblage point' and the trapezoid principle as Left-Hand Path tools for perceptual change and Remanifestation. It draws connections to Chaos Magic elements and Native American medicine wheel traditions, arguing that manipulating these concepts can beneficially shift perception and shape magical realities.

structure_content.chapter_title: Orixás in the Practice of Brazilian Candomblé - by David de Andrade II°
structure_content.summary: This article provides a comprehensive overview of Brazilian Candomblé, tracing its African origins and describing its pantheon of deities, orixás, which represent deified forces of nature and human archetypes. It details their magical associations, gender aspects (metametá), the roles of specific orixás, and the structure of Candomblé rituals, including temple organization and 'Saint' making.

structure_content.chapter_title: Welcome to the Gate of Pergamon! Darest Thou Seek Entry? - by K. Brent Olsen, Gate Keeper
structure_content.summary: This entry describes the 'Gate of Pergamon' as a newly instituted 'Gate of Hell' that has undergone a Xeper-process over millennia. It connects the Gate's symbolism to the historical Pergamon Altar, interpreting its structure as 'ascending man above God' and its founder Telephus as the initiate's mind. It invites aspirants to explore self, control the micro/macrocosm link, and delve into specific occult topics like metagenetics, psychomagnetism, and self-deification within the Gate's 'psychosphere.'

structure_content.chapter_title: Inner Thought Workings - by Jennifer Chen I°
structure_content.summary: This personal reflection recounts the author's transformative experience at a Setian conclave, leading to an 'awakening' of Setian identity and a deeper understanding of what distinguishes Setians from the 'World of Horrors.' It addresses the post-conclave 'blues' upon returning to mundane life and frames Xeper as a terrifying yet divinely beautiful spiritual journey requiring awareness, hard work, and self-transformation for Remanifestation.

structure_content.chapter_title: Bhairava, Lord of Terror - by John A. Wilson II°
structure_content.summary: This analysis delves into the Hindu deity Bhairava, a fearsome manifestation of Siva, as a potent symbol of the Left-Hand Path. It explains Siva's path to enlightenment through antinomian acts (e.g., murder of Brahma), self-torment, and madness, culminating in the 'transcendence of time' (Mahakala) to achieve immortality, linking this to Saturn and the various terrifying forms of Bhairava.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Well of Pythia Remanifests - by Tony Pizzini II°
structure_content.summary: This section offers reviews of various cultural works—musical albums, video games, and artistic concepts—through an occult lens. It highlights their relevance for Setian practice, discussing themes of transformation, dark aesthetics, and esoteric inspiration, making specific recommendations for 'working music' and games with Setian themes.

structure_content.chapter_title: Has Allah Spoken Against That? The Setian in a War Zone - by Brian Karasek II°
structure_content.summary: This article provides a humorous yet practical guide for Setians navigating occult practice in a Muslim war zone (Bahrain). It outlines specific challenges due to cultural intolerance and offers subversive, adaptable methods for performing rituals, invoking elements, and communicating without drawing unwanted attention, emphasizing the antinomian spirit in such restrictive environments.

structure_content.chapter_title: Terra Incognita A Guide to Dark Destinations - by Nikolas Schreck III°
structure_content.summary: This personal narrative details an initiatory journey to Egypt, presented as a crucial 'Dark Destination' for Setians. The author recounts adopting an 'Islamic student' persona to navigate cultural sensitivities, his exploration of historical sites like the Cairo Museum and Seti I's tomb, and his evolving understanding of Set as more aligned with his LHP purpose than Horus, culminating in a profound personal transformation.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Dark Healer - by Brian Karasek II°
structure_content.summary: The author reflects on his past as a 'psychic vampire' using 'Lesser Black Magic' (LBM) for destructive purposes, causing harm and suffering. He then details his realization that these same manipulative skills could be repurposed for healing, describing a personal experience of helping someone recover from heartbreak, thus demonstrating the effective and enjoyable application of LBM for restorative purposes.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Nephilim Element - by Aaron Besson III°
structure_content.summary: This section introduces a new Setian 'Element' dedicated to Remanifesting the Nephilim as a vital archetype within the Æon of Set. It describes the Nephilim as powerful giants from Biblical myth who taught mankind various arts, emphasizing the Element's focus on rediscovering their intrinsic LHP essence and developing 'Nephilimic Black Magic' (NBM) as a sub-strata of GBM for Xeper and personal development.

structure_content.chapter_title: Recognitions
structure_content.summary: This section lists the official recognitions of several Setian members to higher degrees, including Richard D. Gavin to Priesthood (III°), and David de Andrade, Kevin Rockhill, and Brian Z. Karasek to Adept (II°), with their respective sponsors and dates.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Art of Setian Death: A Questionnaire - by Marie Buckner II°
structure_content.summary: This article introduces a study on Setian perspectives of death, Remanifestation, and possible immortality, framing Setian philosophy as 'a-thanatos' (against death) and the alchemical athanor as a process for soul purification. It outlines a questionnaire to gather insights from Setians on their personal experiences and views regarding death.

structure_content.chapter_title: Notes from Neheh - by Don Webb V°, High Priest of Set
structure_content.summary: This multi-part reflection covers the Houston Conclave's magical egregore and its functions. It provides guidance on the Setian approach to member departures (using brutal but charitable analysis for growth). Most significantly, it details the Setian 'Layers of the World' (Surface, Medial, Core, Dæmonic) as both microcosm and macrocosm, explaining how to interact with each layer for self-development and magical influence. It also revisits Lesser Black Magic and introduces the 'Temple-wide North Solstice Working' for practicing resonance and Xeper.

structure_content.chapter_title: Presenting Maat - by David Moore II°
structure_content.summary: This essay critically engages with R.K. Barrett's concept of Maat, proposing an LHP re-interpretation that moves beyond its traditional Osirian 'judgment' context. It redefines Maat as an individual 'quintessence' or 'truth,' formed where power, purity, and will converge, emphasizing that individual Setians create and present their own unique Maat as an expression of godhood and a guide within Xem.

structure_content.chapter_title: Mastering your Memes - by Quintin Phillips II°
structure_content.summary: This technical analysis delves into language and thought using the metaphor of 'word-trees' (memes), explaining how experiences modify perception and how memory/creativity function. It posits that Setians can achieve Xeper by consciously manipulating their 'word-tree forest,' overcoming neural limitations, and becoming 'masters of their memes' by identifying and uprooting 'mystery words' or externally imposed beliefs.

structure_content.chapter_title: Walpurgisnacht Charge - by Jennifer Chen I°
structure_content.summary: This poetic piece describes a personal ritual of initiation and transformation under the 'Black Flame.' It evokes a sense of awakening, standing at the threshold between old and new, greeting the self on the 'other side,' and embracing rebirth and transcendence 'in the shadow of Set' as the first steps in a magical journey.

structure_content.chapter_title: Uniquely Female: Pregnancy as an Initiatory Challenge - by Lauri Jean Crowe II°
structure_content.summary: This article explores pregnancy as a profound Black Magical, LHP initiatory experience for female Setians. It challenges conventional views by framing pregnancy as an embrace of female isolation, an exploration of self and other, and a vehicle for immersing in and mastering emotions for personal growth and Remanifestation, ultimately leading to acting as 'goddesses on earth.'

structure_content.chapter_title: Rise - by Jennifer Chen I°
structure_content.summary: This short, evocative poem speaks of awakening from a shadow, embracing knowledge, and the aspiration of the self to 'rise, to shift, and change,' symbolizing an individual's transformative journey towards their future.

structure_content.chapter_title: Transformation - by Debra A. Hoffmann II°
structure_content.summary: This reflection addresses magical transformation as a painful but ultimately liberating 'birth process' during chaotic periods. It emphasizes the need for 'faith'—not mindless belief, but trusting one's true nature and intuition—to navigate these changes, likening the process to the Tarot's 'Fool' card taking a leap of faith, and growing by trusting the self despite mundane doubts.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Divine Dream - by James Knowles III°
structure_content.summary: This philosophical inquiry delves into the nature of Set's 'divine dream' and the initiate's conscious (Re)manifestation within it. It poses questions about existence, death, and how individual consciousness perpetuates Set's dream, suggesting that by 'Remanifesting my own individual consciousness into my own divine dream,' the initiate emulates Set.

structure_content.chapter_title: Psychobabble - by Larry Evans III°
structure_content.summary: This critical commentary defines 'psychobabble' as overly technical or jargon-filled language that hinders communication among Setians. It advocates for clarity, simplicity, and empathy in expression to ensure broader understanding and effective dialogue, referencing Magus Webb's distinction between LBM and 'LWM' (Lesser White Magic) and Ipsissimus Lewis's advice on straightforward communication.

structure_content.chapter_title: Thoughts on Set - by Behni Napper I°
structure_content.summary: This article presents a personal perspective on Set as an active entity who initiated the Universe's motion by acting as an antagonist against stasis, awakening the sleeper, and providing the foundation of Maat (order without stasis). It views Set as a giver of awakening and a plan for individual godhood, encouraging Setians to act as antagonists against unwanted stasis in their lives.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Coming Into Being of the Pesh-Khent Pylon, Finland - by Markku Siira II°, Sentinel
structure_content.summary: This announcement details the establishment of the Pesh-Khent Pylon in Finland, a 'Xeper-enhancing environment' named after Set's knife. It outlines the Pylon's focus on studying Setian philosophy, Hermeticism, Gnosticism, Dark Light Sufism, and other occult systems, emphasizing experimental GBM/LBM/MBM workings, the importance of its egregore, and collaboration with other Nordic Pylons.

key_concepts.definition: The core Setian principle of self-creation and becoming, often described as a spiritual journey that is both terrifying and beautiful, involving the transformation of the self and conscious (Re)manifestation.

Words like Xeper, Thelema, or Agape that are understood as 'worlds' or environments unto themselves, shaping the experiences and perspectives of their adherents. They are not necessarily sequential or exclusive.

The process of bringing something new into being or altering existing reality, whether through shifts in the assemblage point, conscious self-transformation, or the willed creation of new universes. It is a key outcome of Setian magical practice.

A spiritual and magical path focused on individual self-development, self-deification, and transcending limitations, often through antinomian or transgressive acts, as opposed to paths that merge with a collective or external deity (RHP).

A concept from nagualism (Carlos Castaneda) describing a location on a human's 'luminous cocoon' where all fibers of the universe are focused into perception. Shifting this point through 'intent' leads to perceptual changes, potentially resulting in Remanifestation or the perception of new universes.

Ka is defined as a 'changeless force working on the world,' representing a specific purpose or driving principle that guides actions and informs success or failure. 'Kaw' (plural) are these forces, which can often be in conflict with each other.

Traditionally the Egyptian goddess of truth and justice. In a Setian context, it is re-interpreted as 'individual Maat' or 'individual truth,' representing the 'sentience of the nexus' where a magician's power, purity, and will converge into meaning and quintessence, serving as a guide for individual godhood.

A collective thought-form or non-physical entity created by a group of people through shared intent, purpose, and resonant action. In the Temple of Set, egregores can draw new members, reveal enemies, boost initiates, and store power.

key_concepts.term: Lesser Black Magic (LBM) / Greater Black Magic (GBM)
key_concepts.definition: LBM involves manipulating others or circumstances for personal gain, often without concern for who gets credit, and can be used for both destructive (e.g., 'psychic vampirism') and constructive purposes (e.g., healing). GBM focuses on the understanding of the personal qualities of the process of Xeper.

A Setian model dividing existence into four levels: Surface (here-and-now activities, freedom), Medial (programming, goals, dreams, self-knowledge, magic), Core (unchangeable self, individuality, Principle of Isolate Self-Consciousness), and Dæmonic (magical currents, access to non-chronological data, inherited/invoked magic). These layers exist both microcosmically (within the self) and macrocosmically (within the cosmos), interacting through resonance.

Mental packages or interpreters for the objective universe, built from physical interactions and associations that form subjective perception. They are analogous to 'memes,' and Setians aim to consciously manipulate their 'word-tree forest' to achieve Xeper by mastering their thoughts and beliefs.

Described in the context of the Gate of Pergamon, it serves as an initiate's primary ritual chamber for exploring specific occult topics (e.g., metagenetics, psychomagnetism, Luciferian illumination, self-deification) to develop control over the link between the microcosm and macrocosm.

practical_system.description: The document outlines a multifaceted practical system rooted in Setian philosophy, emphasizing individual Xeper and Remanifestation. It integrates diverse magical methodologies (e.g., Chaos Magic, nagualism, LBM/GBM, modified Candomblé principles) tailored for self-development and influencing both the microcosm and macrocosm. The system is characterized by conscious effort, critical self-analysis, and the re-interpretation of traditional concepts through an LHP lens.
tools: Æonic Words (Xeper, Remanifest, Xem) as conceptual 'worlds' for shaping reality
The 'Assemblage Point' (a conceptual locus of perception, manipulable by 'intent' for perceptual shifts)
Trapezoid Principle (a geometric form used in architecture and magic to induce perceptual changes and shift the assemblage point)
Medicine Wheel (a Native American concept for balancing perception and shifting the assemblage point through symbolic correspondences)
The 'Layers of the World' model (a four-tiered framework – Surface, Medial, Core, Dæmonic – for self-analysis and engaging with the cosmos on different magical levels)
'Word-trees' or 'Memes' (conceptual structures of language and thought, to be consciously manipulated for altering perception and achieving 'mastery of one's memes')
Magical Diary (for recording and analyzing magical experiences, particularly LBM, to gain self-knowledge and refine practice)
Psychonomic practicum and theory (methods for self-exploration and understanding applied in the context of the Gate of Pergamon)
Maat (re-interpreted as individual truth and quintessence, serving as a 'map' or 'guide' for the initiate's journey within Xem)
The Black Flame (a central Setian symbol, representing the spark of consciousness and the driving force of initiation)
rituals: Houston Regional Conclave ritual workings (e.g., shape-shifting, Saturnine magic, Lady Arkte invocation, egregore forging)
Creating a Ka (conscious focus and intent to bring a changeless force/purpose into being for individual accomplishment)

Temple-wide North Solstice Working (a structured ritual involving seven individually chosen Xeper tasks, distinct utterances of 'Set' and 'Xeper,' and subsequent meditation/analysis, not to be discussed until completed)
Lesser Black Magic (conscious use of power for either harm or healing, often involving 'giving up ego for power' and analyzing experiences through a magical diary for self-knowledge)
Setian email communication guidelines (a form of social magic focused on clarity, empathy, and avoiding negativity in community interaction)

'Setian in a War Zone' practical magic (subversive methods for ritual practice in restrictive environments, including preparing a chamber, specific dress codes, quiet invocation, symbolic use of 'Grail' liquids, and invoking desert spirits)
Pergamon Gate entry (dedication to self-exploration, control of microcosm-macrocosm link, and study of specific occult topics like metagenetics and self-deification within the 'psychosphere')
Walpurgisnacht Charge (a personal ritual of initiation and transformation under the 'Black Flame', involving embracing rebirth and transcending in the shadow of Set)

Pregnancy as an Initiatory Challenge (framing the physical, mental, and emotional aspects of pregnancy as a Black Magical process for embracing female isolation, exploring self/other, and mastering emotions for Remanifestation)

relevant_quotes.text: Xeper is an Æonic Word, like Thelema or Agape. Æonic Words are, as Magus Webb describes, “worlds". They are environments unto themselves and their adherents.
The Curse of the Magus: that he causes the Universe to give birth to something it does not want.
Once spoken by its Magus, an Æonic Word brings into being something which was not, but now is — something which must strain against the momentum of reality.
The ka is a changeless force Working on the world.
Xeper means: “I am no longer a servant to my memes; I am their master."
LBM is a conscious effort. What most occultniks inside or outside of our walls use is "LWM" - chanting nonsense.
It is each magician's task to comprehend truth (Maat) and to Become it.
Only this isolation and self-torment was enough for Siva to transcend the oppressive control of that which is mightier than all, time.

critical_analysis.relevance: This issue of 'The Scroll of Set' is highly relevant within Western Esotericism and Setianism as it showcases the ongoing philosophical development, practical applications of magic, and community dynamics of the Temple of Set in 1998. It demonstrates an active engagement with core Setian principles (Xeper, Remanifestation) and their integration into diverse occult traditions, from Chaos Magic and Nagualism to Candomblé and Hinduism. The articles highlight the Setian emphasis on individual godhood, self-transformation through challenging experiences (e.g., pregnancy, war zones), and the critical analysis of both internal (memes, layers of self) and external (Æonic Words, egregore) magical forces. The discussions on 'psychobabble' and communication ethics further reveal the intellectual rigor and self-awareness within the Setian community.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience is Setian initiates of all degrees, particularly those actively engaged in the practical application of Left Hand Path philosophy, self-development, and esoteric research within the Temple of Set. It also appeals to practitioners of Chaos Magic, Nagualism, and other modern occult movements who are interested in advanced magical theory, personal transformation, and comparative esotericism.
